notes: On 14 November 2019, in Djibouti, residents of Arhiba organized a sit-in to denounce the two weeks detention of activist Kako Homad Kako by the Djiboutian police.[size=no report]
On 3 Novembre 2019, in Djibouti, opposition leader Kako Houmed Kako was placed in provisory detention by the tribunal of Djibouti. The motives behind his inculpation remain unknown.
On 1 November 2019, a protest to denounce the arrest of Kako Houmed Kako was held in Obock.[size=no report]
On 1 November 2019, a protest to denounce the arrest of Kako Houmed Kako was held in Randa.[size=no report]
On 1 November 2019, a protest to denounce the arrest of Kako Houmed Kako was held in Tadjourah. [size=no report]
On 31 Octotber 2019, in Djibouti, opposition leader Kako Houmed Kako was arrested by the Djiboutian police and transferred to an unknown place.

On 31 October 2019, in Arhiba (south of Djibouti city), for 24 hours, protestors demonstrated against the arrest of Kako Houmed Kako by the police. The use of real bullets by the police was reported in response. According to the human rights Djiboutian league dozens of protestors where injured and arrested.[size=no report]
On 27 October 2019, in Djibouti journalist Osman Yonis Bogoreh was arrested for a secong time by the Djiboutian police after his release a day before.
On 26 October 2019, in Goubetto, journalist Osman Yonis Bogoreh, was reported to be tortured for 48 hours by the Djiboutian police before his release.
On 30 September 2019, young graduate unemployed held a peaceful protest in Djibouti against austerity, poverty and unemployment. [size=no report]
On or around 16 September 2019, armed clashes were reported in As Eyla, Dikhil region between Afar and Issa groups. At least one person was injured.
On 11 September 2019, Gadidche Ladieh Omar was tortured and murdered in detention at the Nagad Police Academy.
On or around 3 September 2019, several policemen attacked and beat the Chief of Service for the Port, inside his vehicle.
On August 26, in Medeho, Mabla-Obock village, Military forces allegedly opened fire on herdsmen following the killing of a soldier's dog. No fatalities reported.
On June 10 (or around), in Tadjourah, military forces shot at civilians, killing three and injuring an unknown number.

On May 8, in Balbalaa, in Djibouti's neighbourhood, workers of the Djibouti Agency of Roads (ADR) demonstrated to demand better working conditions. They reportedly burned tires. Rioters were arrested by police forces, and released later the same day. [size=no report]
On the night of April 11-12, between Dikhil and As Eyla, a military patrol fighting smugglers shot at a bus, injuring two civilians.
On Dec 21, in Djibouti, French djihadist Peter Cherif was arrested by Djibouti Forces.
Agreement: 07 September. Eritrea and Djibouti have signed a peace deal in Djibouti after years of stand off over border conflicts.

On 14 May, a youth demonstration over the results of a career recruitment drive for a newly constructed port led to clashes with police in Tadjourah. 80 people were arrested and released later on. The youth blocked roads, stoned the security forces and ransacked the Regional Council offices.

On 27th October, peaceful protests occurred in Tadjourah, northern Djibouti, where a port is to be built. The protesters were demanding jobs. Several demonstrators were injured when the police used live ammo and teargas to disperse the protesters

On October 8, early in the morning, Military forces' bulldozers entered Balbala and demolished buildings and houses. In reaction, inhabitants, mostly from Issa ethncity, threw rocks and Molotov cocktails at soldiers. Military forces allegedly shot at inhabitants, injuring 9. 100 people were arrested. [size=no report]

In mid-June 2017, a youth protest demanding better access to jobs in the new Port of Tadjourah was cut short when security officials detained several dozen protesters at the Tadjourah Gendarmerie headquarters

In early March 2017, the famous caricaturist Idriss Hassan Mohamed was arrested and held in an undisclosed location for five days. According to LDDH, his leg was broken during interrogation and detention. LDDH claims he was arrested in retaliation for an article he published criticising the regime

On January 14, authorities in Balbala reportedly arrested president of the Opposition Youth Movement and USN activist Zakaria Rirache Miguil during a meeting of opposition youth in his home. He was suspected of plotting to organise protests against President Guelleh's candidacy for a fourth mandate. He was allegedly tortured while detained
Police reportedly shot and wounded three Oromo refugees in Djibouti as the refugees were protesting having to pay bribes to police in order to register with UNHCR.

actor2: FRUD: Front of the Restoration of Unity and Democracy
notes: FRUD forces attacked government soldiers at Margoita camp, leaving soldiers with injuries and stealing armaments.

actor2: FRUD: Front of the Restoration of Unity and Democracy
notes: Soldiers pushed away FRUD forces, including FRUD forces crossing from Ethiopia, on Yager mount in an attack on 15 August, leading to some injuries among soldiers.
Agents of the Gendarmerie in Ali Sabieh allegedly arrested and beat a civilian without charge.

Kadar Abdi Ibrahim, publication co-director of the Aurore newspaper, was arrested by police in connection with the publication of a photograph of a seven-year-old girl who died during the violent dispersal of a religious ceremony by the police and the Djibouti army on 21 December 2015. He was reportedly tortured in detention. He was later condemned to a two-month suspended prison sentence, while the publication of this monthly newspaper was also suspended for two months.

Up to 27 people were reportedly killed and 150 injured in clashes between police, troops and armed members of the Yonis Moussa community in Balbala. Numbers provided by the International federation for Human Rights (FIDH) and the opposition are three times higher than authorities. Authorities reported that opponents attacked them armed with knives, machetes and two Kalashnikov guns, while the opposition emphasised they were attending a banned religious gathering when security forces attacked them. 17 people were arrested following the clashes, including members of the opposition coalition Union for National Salvation (USN).

assoc_actor_2: LDDH: Djiboutian League of Human Rights
notes: On 10 December 2015, Said Hussein Robleh, the secretary general of LDDH and an opposition member of parliament, was insulted and publicly beaten by the Chief of Police while sitting in a cafe. He sustained serious injuries and was forced to seek medical assistance
Police violently arrested a young member of the Youth Opposition Movement (MJO). He was held at Gabode prison in harsh conditions and severely beaten during the course of his arrest.

Police violently arrested six minors aged between 13 and 15 years from the Movement for Democratic Renewal (MRD) - a National Salvation Union (USN) party - in the Balbala Sheikh Moussa neighbourhood in Djibouti City, at a peaceful celebration before ransacking the partys premises. The minors were held at Gabode prison in harsh conditions

Seven people have been arrested over suspected links to the rebel Front for the Restoration of Unity and Democracy (FRUD). In total, 15 people have been put behind bars for their alledged link to FRUD. they have alledgedly been systematically tortured since their arrest

Arrests: Young members of the Union for National Salvation (USN) and the Opposition Youth Movement (MJO), as well as two USN leaders, were arbitrarily detained in Gabode prison following a first instance trial after having been arrested on 18 September for having participated in a demonstration. they were released on 11 October

There were protests in Djibouti led by the opposition Union for National Salvation party against a third term bid for the head of state. Police shot one of the protesters and later on arrested around 20 people.
The regime in Djibouti organized protests in support of the head of states fourth term bid

The President and the Spokesman for Mouvement des Jeunes de lopposition were arrested in their homes and beaten by police. They were denied access to a lawyer or doctor and placed in Gabode prison until one was released Dec 14th.

Djibouti Republican Guard has suddenly opened fire today at the Djibouti International Airport, injuring two people, including a senior officer.

In August 2014, journalist Mohamed Ibrahim Waiss was arrested and detained, in Djibouti City, and accused of 'incitement and publishing false news.'
